articles.headline: Inflation Slowed Last Month
articles.snippet: Inflation slowed sharply last month, the Labor Department reported yesterday, providing comfort to many investors that the Federal Reserve might be moving closer to ending its campaign of raising interest rates.     In another report also suggesti...
articles.abstract: Inflation slowed sharply last month, the Labor Department reported yesterday, providing comfort to many investors that the Federal Reserve might be moving closer to ending its campaign of raising interest rates.     In another report also suggesting that interest rates might not need to go much higher, the Commerce Department said construction of new homes slowed sharply in February from the frenetic pace set in January. The number of homes under construction continued to rise, though, reaching a 32-year high.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inflation slowed sharply last month, the Labor Department reported yesterday, providing comfort to many investors that the Federal Reserve might be moving closer to ending its campaign of raising interest rates.

articles.headline: Students Flock to Seminaries, but Fewer See Pulpit in Future
articles.snippet: Among the important things Kirkland Reynolds has figured out in his three years in the seminary is that he does not want to be a church pastor.      Like many young people here at the Candler School of Theology at Emory University, Mr. Reynolds, 2...
articles.abstract: Among the important things Kirkland Reynolds has figured out in his three years in the seminary is that he does not want to be a church pastor.      Like many young people here at the Candler School of Theology at Emory University, Mr. Reynolds, 24, hopes to put his religious education to some other use, saying he does not want to preach or take a position of authority in the community.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA - Among the important things Kirkland Reynolds has figured out in his three years in the seminary is that he does not want to be a church pastor.

articles.headline: Officer Krupke, the Merger Made Me Do It
articles.snippet: DO big bank mergers lead to more crime? And is that a reason to toughen antitrust enforcement?     The idea sounds unlikely, and admittedly the effect is a small one. But a persuasive new study published in the April issue of The Journal of Financ...
articles.abstract: DO big bank mergers lead to more crime? And is that a reason to toughen antitrust enforcement?     The idea sounds unlikely, and admittedly the effect is a small one. But a persuasive new study published in the April issue of The Journal of Finance finds a relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: DO big bank mergers lead to more crime? And is that a reason to toughen antitrust enforcement?

articles.headline: Surgical Device Poses a Rare but Serious Peril
articles.snippet: Kristina A. Fox entered a Portland, Ore., hospital in the fall of 1998 hoping a routine, minimally invasive form of surgery called laparoscopy would relieve a painful gynecological condition.     She went home the same day destined to become part ...
articles.abstract: Kristina A. Fox entered a Portland, Ore., hospital in the fall of 1998 hoping a routine, minimally invasive form of surgery called laparoscopy would relieve a painful gynecological condition.     She went home the same day destined to become part of a simmering debate over whether medical device makers and health care providers have been overlooking -- some would say ignoring -- an easily preventable, but potentially devastating, laparoscopy hazard.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kristina A. Fox entered a Portland, Ore., hospital in the fall of 1998 hoping a routine, minimally invasive form of surgery called laparoscopy would relieve a painful gynecological condition.

articles.headline: U.S. and Iranians Agree to Discuss Violence in Iraq
articles.snippet: Iran and the United States agreed Thursday to hold direct talks on how to halt sectarian violence and restore calm in Iraq, offering the first face-to-face conversation between the sides after months of confrontation over Iran's nuclear program.  ...
articles.abstract: Iran and the United States agreed Thursday to hold direct talks on how to halt sectarian violence and restore calm in Iraq, offering the first face-to-face conversation between the sides after months of confrontation over Iran's nuclear program.      Iran's chief nuclear negotiator, Ali Larijani, announced in Iran's Parliament on Thursday that he would send a team of negotiators to Iraq to meet with American representatives there. But he also suggested in an interview that there would be stiff preconditions.
articles.byline: By Michael Slackman and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: G.M. Loss for 2005 Is Steeper
articles.snippet: General Motors on Thursday reported a revised and steeper loss for 2005, increasing the amount to $10.6 billion, or $2 billion more than it reported in January.     G.M. said the revision was the result of higher costs of scaling back its North Am...
articles.abstract: General Motors on Thursday reported a revised and steeper loss for 2005, increasing the amount to $10.6 billion, or $2 billion more than it reported in January.     G.M. said the revision was the result of higher costs of scaling back its North American operations and of helping its former parts subsidiary, Delphi, restructure while in bankruptcy protection.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, March 16 - General Motors on Thursday reported a revised and steeper loss for 2005, increasing the amount to $10.6 billion, or $2 billion more than it reported in January.

articles.headline: Democracy Push by Bush Attracts Doubters in Party
articles.snippet: Even as it presents an updated national security strategy, the Bush administration is facing fresh doubts from some Republicans who say its emphasis on promoting democracy around the world has come at the expense of protecting other American inter...
articles.abstract: Even as it presents an updated national security strategy, the Bush administration is facing fresh doubts from some Republicans who say its emphasis on promoting democracy around the world has come at the expense of protecting other American interests.     The second thoughts signify a striking change in mood over one of President Bush's cherished tenets, pitting Republicans who call themselves realists against the neoconservatives who saw the invasion of Iraq as a catalyst for change and who remain the most vigorous advocates of a muscular American campaign to foster democratic movements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as it presents an updated national security strategy, the Bush administration is facing fresh doubts from some Republicans who say its emphasis on promoting democracy around the world has come at the expense of protecting other American interests.

articles.headline: Same Washington, Different Office
articles.snippet: As attorney general, John Ashcroft was a model of moral rectitude to his conservative supporters. To his liberal detractors, he was overly self-righteous. Mr. Ashcroft sees himself simply as a man of integrity, and to him that is worth a lot.     ...
articles.abstract: As attorney general, John Ashcroft was a model of moral rectitude to his conservative supporters. To his liberal detractors, he was overly self-righteous. Mr. Ashcroft sees himself simply as a man of integrity, and to him that is worth a lot.      So in the era of the Jack Abramoff scandal, Mr. Ashcroft has become a Washington lobbyist, setting himself up as something of an anti-Abramoff and marketing his insider's knowledge of how Washington works.

articles.headline: U.S. Assault on Insurgents
articles.snippet: The United States military began a large-scale assault on insurgent bases near Samarra, with aircraft, armored vehicles and 1,500 American and Iraqi troops. Page A12.
articles.abstract: The United States military began a large-scale assault on insurgent bases near Samarra, with aircraft, armored vehicles and 1,500 American and Iraqi troops. Page A12.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States military began a large-scale assault on insurgent bases near Samarra, with aircraft, armored vehicles and 1,500 American and Iraqi troops. Page A12.

articles.headline: Senate Approves Budget, Breaking Spending Limits
articles.snippet: The Senate narrowly approved a $2.8 trillion election-year budget Thursday that broke spending limits only hours after it increased federal borrowing power to avert a government default.      The budget decision at the end of a marathon day of vot...
articles.abstract: The Senate narrowly approved a $2.8 trillion election-year budget Thursday that broke spending limits only hours after it increased federal borrowing power to avert a government default.      The budget decision at the end of a marathon day of voting followed a separate 52-to-48 Senate vote to increase the federal debt limit by $781 billion, bringing the debt ceiling to nearly $9 trillion. The move left Democrats attacking President Bush and Congressional Republicans for piling up record debt in their years in power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 16 - The Senate narrowly approved a $2.8 trillion election-year budget Thursday that broke spending limits only hours after it increased federal borrowing power to avert a government default.

articles.headline: Kurds Destroy Monument in Rage at Leadership
articles.snippet: For nearly two decades, Kurds have gathered peacefully in this mountainous corner of northern Iraq to commemorate one of the blackest days in their history. It was here that Saddam Hussein's government launched a poison gas attack that killed more...
articles.abstract: For nearly two decades, Kurds have gathered peacefully in this mountainous corner of northern Iraq to commemorate one of the blackest days in their history. It was here that Saddam Hussein's government launched a poison gas attack that killed more than 5,000 people on March 16, 1988.     So it came as a shock when hundreds of stone-throwing protesters took to the streets here Thursday on the anniversary, beating back government guards to storm and destroy a museum dedicated to the memory of the Halabja attack.
